author: @KnittedScarf1915
text: I am a Data Analyst. My pathway was at University during my Geography degree where I learnt how to build a geospatial database (in Esri ArcGIS) and query it using SQL (I had previous html/css/php and mysql knowledge). I then wanted to analyse these very large environmental datasets, so I learnt R code and statistics. When I became more advanced lockdown happened,  I learnt Python and Linux (kali). I am now in a data analyst role where I am now having to pick up Power BI. Along the way I also learnt GIT and Docker.  If it wasn't for GIS I wouldn't be a Data Analyst :)

author: @devinah4706
text: *STEP 1* Learning the right skills (2~3 months, 1~2 hours a day) _- SQL_ _- Tableau / Power BI_ _- Excel_ _- Python_  *STEP 2* Create portfolio website (1 month) + Build good projects  *STEP 3* Create a data analyst resume (1 week) + Update LinkedIn (1 week) + Working with recruiters (3 weeks)  *WHERE TO LEARN* YouTube (e.g. Alex's channel) Coursera _- IBM Data Analyst Professional Certificate_ _- Google Data Analytics Professional Certificate_

author: @marcinkrzysztof6084
text: Hi Alex, I  just became a Data Analyst. Your materials among the others were very helpful. In my case the key aspects were:  1. As you said in video, right skills are a must; 2. Resume (the best option is to ask headhunter, recruiter how it should look); 3. If you think you have some data skills and your resume looks fine DON'T BE AFRAID TO APPLY for the positions within (and slighlty out of) your reach. I got a job even tho I wasn't fully qualified for every requirement. So guys the key rule is to learn and don't underestimate yourself. Fingers crossed for y'all!
